text:
When I think of a cell - like the biological kind 
- I automatically think of something super-tiny. I

mean, the very definition of a cell has to do with 
its smallness. But cells don’t have to be small.

A single-celled organism known as a xenophyophore 
can get nearly as big as a volleyball - one cell,

in a single membrane! - and the nerve cell that 
connects a giraffe’s larynx to its brain can

be several meters long. But the heaviest 
cell on our planet today exists in here.

Welcome to MinuteEarth.
An egg - the cell that sperm fertilize to

produce a baby - is generally the largest cell 
that an organism produces. Which makes sense;

in animals that grow their babies internally, 
the egg has to provide everything needed to

nourish and power the embryo before it implants 
and can start grabbing resources from its mom,

so that egg has to be pretty big. And the eggs 
of animals that grow into babies outside their

mom - like birds’ - need to be even bigger, since 
they have to contain essentially everything needed

to develop into a baby from start to finish. 
When an egg meets sperm, it starts to divide,

turning one large cell into many different smaller 
cells. But an egg that never gets fertilized never

divides. In most animals, an unfertilized egg 
will just get reabsorbed by the mom’s body.

But for animals that make those super-big egg 
cells - like birds - it’s easier to just lay an

unfertilized egg than reabsorb the whole thing. 
It ends up as a single giant cell - in a shell:

a glorious golden blob that might not make a 
baby, but does make an egg-cell-ent breakfast.

And speaking of delicious things, 
we’ve cooked up something new:

MinuteFood, a channel that explores food and 
cooking through the lens of science. You’ll get

to join me in my own kitchen while I dig into the 
science of what we cook, eat, and drink, all with

the goal of getting better in the kitchen. And 
we’re not talking fancy techniques here - I’m a

home cook - I just want to eat delicious food. 
So if you want to know what physics says about

how to not overcook your steak, or how to use 
chemistry to make garlic taste better, head over

to MinuteFood, where we’ve just started serving 
up piping-hot videos - no reservations required.

And if you want MinuteFood to keep dishing up 
fun, fresh episodes, be sure to support our

tasty sponsor, HelloFresh. I love to cook - I 
mean, I’m launching a new YouTube channel about

cooking - but that doesn't mean I always have 
lots of time to spend cooking dinner. So there is

nothing better than when that big green HelloFresh 
box shows up at my door and all I have to do

is pick which awesome recipe to make - because, 
seriously, they’re really good. Plus, since a lot

of the recipes are really quick - we’re talking, 
like less than 30 minutes - and the ingredients

are all pre-measured out, it’s the perfect way 
to cook with my kids. My four-year-old is totally

obsessed with HelloFresh - she’s even more excited 
about that big green box arriving than I am! If

you, too, would like your kid to be super-excited 
to cook dinner with you, go to HelloFresh.com and

use code EARTH16 for up to 16 free meals and 3 
surprise gifts. Again, that's 16 free meals and

3 surprise gifts at HelloFresh.com with promo code 
EARTH16! And with all that time you’re saving now

that cooking dinner is a total breeze, be sure 
to check out our fresh new channel, MinuteFood.
